turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in Torres against Puerto Rico.
I think we will wait a moment for the audience to clear.
They seem to have a lot of interest in broadcasting today.
Mr. Remcho, I think you may now proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

This case presents the question whether the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico may constitutionally enact and enforce a statute authorizing its police to conduct indiscriminate warrantless searches of the luggage, packages, bundles and bags of persons arriving in Puerto Rico from the mainland United States.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now in that you include I take it the power to examine everything that comes in, just the way customs agents do at Mexican border or anywhere else, is that what you mean to embrace by indiscriminate?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: What I mean to embrace by indiscriminate is as the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico found, the statute Public Law 22 authorizes the individual police officer, not a customs official, but the individual police officer.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does it make any difference whether it is a police officer or a customs official or what name you give the person?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, I think it makes a substantial difference.
That goes to the whole question of whether Puerto Rico may in the first place, setup any kind of a customs search.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's what I am trying to get at.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: So let me get to that question then directly and take up the others later.

The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico was created by the Commonwealth Compact, but nothing in that Compact reserved to Puerto Rico the right in any fashion to setup its own border between the United States and Puerto Rico.
In fact, with respect to customs, 19 US Code Section 1202(a) specifically includes Puerto Rico within United States customs territory.

The Commonwealth Compact itself and the additional Puerto Rico Federal Relations Act, includes a carefully considered set of regulations and a compact between the United States Congress and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico with respect to how those two parties will relate to each other and there is nothing in that compact, which I find which specifically or implicitly authorizes Puerto Rico to setup any kind of a border between itself and the United States.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You are limiting that of course to travelers from the United States, aren't you?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, that is great, that is what the statute says, but that is what a border is all about; people coming from one place to the other regardless of whether they are residents of Puerto Rico or the United States mainland.
The Commonwealth has taken the position with respect to the border not that they have the power or have indeed created anything like an international border.
The position they took below at least was that they had the power to create a functional equivalent of a border.
And I think that misconstrues this Court's cases with respect to what a functional equivalent of a border is.
As the Court held in Almeida-Sanchez, the functional equivalent of a border is basically the same thing as a border only for practical necessary reasons that border has been moved.

So for example, St. Louis is the functional equivalent of the United States border for a person arriving for the first time in United States and the confluence of two or three roads right near the Mexican-United States border is the functional equivalent of the border and that is the only practical place where US customs officials can conduct their duties.

The defect here is in going back to your initial question is that the border search cases, which allowed even certain exceptions, which setup the functional equivalent system and allowed certain exceptions to normal probable cause, excuse me, to normal search and stop procedures, where search is conducted by customs officials and persons authorized to do that, and that by its very nature, limited the type of the search.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't the United States put policemen on the border between Mexico and the United States?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: As such, there is no magic in the word customs, is there?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: There is no magic in the word customs.
You can clearly put one there if there is in fact an international border, but I think the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: There is and I am talking about the Mexican border right now.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Absolutely, you can put –-

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They are customs agents. Could they change their title to policemen?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And do the same thing?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Absolutely.

But the analogy I think as to when you can put a policeman there and when you put someone else there, applies more to what is sometimes used as inspection searches that is where State of California may setup an inspection point for pest and plant material coming in from Arizona.

In a situation like that, clearly they can't setup and have never tried to setup police officers to search people coming from Arizona to California, but they have had a very limited scope of authority covered by regulatory discretion for health officials to examine matter coming in.
And so, there is a distinction in that thing between a police officer and a customs type official.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let me ask something about fact here.
Is the appellant a United States citizen?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: He is a United States citizen, I am not sure if the record reflects that fact.
In fact, it does not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where does he reside?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: He resides in the State of Florida.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Remcho, you are arguing the Fourth Amendment here I take it.
Does the Fourth Amendment plane out so to speak limit the authority of the Puerto Rican legislature?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: The Fourth Amendment in my view clearly limits the authority of the Puerto Rican legislature, that is correct, and I would say in any one of the four rationale that we set forth in our brief.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Either because it is analogous to a state and the Fourth Amendment is incorporated by the Fourteenth?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: No.

I think Mr. Justice Rehnquist, I was persuaded by your dissent in Otero that in passing the Thirteenth and Fourteenth amendments, clearly distinction was made between a state and something, which is not a state.
So, I am not arguing that the Fourteenth Amendment in and off itself carries the Fourth Amendment into Puerto Rico in the traditional incorporation doctrine.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We are on pretty thin ground, if you are persuaded by my dissent in Otero, since you presumably have eight people versus one person?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, I am persuaded only by the point that the Fourteenth Amendment does not apply directly in the same fashion as if Puerto Rico were a state.
I am not saying that that is what does it.

What I am saying is that what I take it the majority meant in that case was that when Congress pursuant to its territorial power created this compact with the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and said that all the constitutional provisions not inapplicable will apply, that the Fourth Amendment applies in that manner, and through that way, but I do not -- So that is how it applies as a state.
Congress said it will apply as if it were a state.
I do not read the opinion to say anything other than it applies just like the Fourteenth Amendment by necessarily it comes directly from it.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So, and the Fourth Amendment prohibits unreasonable searches?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now, I take it in times of emergency, a city or a particular area can declare a curfew that it couldn't declare it other times without violating the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I suppose that would depend very much on the facts of the situation but I concede that is possible at some point.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So supposing that Puerto Rican legislature here had decided that there was, and I gather from the opinions of the three justices in the minority in the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico that there was a real crime wave and a drug wave in Puerto Rico and that a great deal of it was the result of people coming into Puerto Rico from the United States.

Do you think it is wholly beyond reason to think that the Fourth Amendment would permit airport searches of luggages where you do not have homes involved or you can perhaps stop all that traffic in one public area?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I do think it is wholly unreasonable.

I think that in the first place, there are absolutely no facts in any offered by the government or in the legislative finding that there is a danger from these guns, which supports anything other than a generalized statement that there is a danger.

When I spoke of a curfew, I could see it in a narrow situation when perhaps you know, if there is an earthquake in San Francisco, you can impose a curfew, but to say that you could impose a curfew at any time because of a non-differentiated, generalized concern about the con problem is to just totally ignore the 200 centuries of Fourth Amendment jurisprudence, which you said --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Two centuries.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Two centuries, excuse me, almost two centuries.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You won on this issue?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I am sorry.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You won on this issue, the Puerto Rican Supreme Court agreed with you?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And as I read the brief of your colleague on the bottom side of this case, he does not dispute that decision now.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I read it the same way.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And, so there is no issue between you on the Fourth Amendment or on the ability to search or on the border question?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I think that is probably correct.
If in fact, this Court accepts the concession of the government below as I hope it will, I think that is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh!

Yes, but then he says that, that leaves only the issue, which you want to argue about the failure of the court below to give you relief because of the four-three rule or the majority rule, the "super-majority" rule?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, if in fact he has conceded the Fourth Amendment issue, I do not care about the other issue, because that decides this case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know, but I would think you would because there is a judgment outstanding against you.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: If this Court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If we agree with you and apparently your colleague about the Fourth Amendment issue, then since we do not have any such "super-majority" rule here, we would simply reverse the judgment, wouldn't we?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is what I am asking, and I think --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Wouldn't it follow?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Yes, it would, that is what we would ask the Court to do.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We would have to hold that it is unconstitutional to have that "super-majority"?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why would we?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Why would you have to hold that it is unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there not a judgment outstanding against you now?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct, okay.
We are in the same position in this Court, I take it, as if we had lost seven-nothing below.
We did not lose seven-nothing below.
We lost four-three to below pursuant to that particular Puerto Rico constitutional provision.
A judgment was entered against us.
We made a timely appeal to this Court.
The judgment upheld the validity of the conviction.
What we are asking this Court to do is to reverse that conviction; to say that the Fourth Amendment prohibits that search and judgment for the appellant has to be entered.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You suppose this could be an adequate state ground on direct appeal, but nevertheless not bar federal habeas corpus?
Other things are?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I do not think, it was not decided on an adequate -- the judgment entered was against --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know it was decided that they – the court below refused to get you relief because a majority of that court did not join in the opinion?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which is a characteristic of local law, and if we can redirect another judgment to be entered by that court unless we hold that provision is unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I think you can.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Perhaps a federal habeas corpus court can order release because in that event, there would be no necessity to declare anything unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I think you can and the reason is this.
The government appealed at the time; both two things.
We appealed; the government contended at that time and continued to contend until recently that, that Fourth Amendment judgment was wrong.
If this Court, which is a final arbitrator of the Fourth Amendment says to the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico, we tell you that that you were right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That you were right --

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: You were right --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That you were quite right.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Yes, and as soon as we tell the Court that and declare that this statute is unconstitutional, then that Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They have already declared it, but they say we have no power under the Puerto Rican Law to reverse this judgment; we just do not have that power?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I understand that.
They do not have the power.
If it is they who say that the statute is unconstitutional.
If this Court says that the statute is unconstitutional, there is nothing in the Puerto Rico constitution, which prohibits that Court from entering judgment favoring the appellant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say the Akron against Bryant point may well be an adequate state ground, but the decision on the merits of the Fourth Amendment question is not?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: No, I am not saying that the Akron versus Bryant may be inadequate state ground at all.
What I am saying, I am saying that the decision in Akron is wrong, excuse me, that the decision below upholding that judgment while they thought the statute was not constitutional, is incorrect.

I am saying, you do not necessarily have to reach the issue of whether Akron was wrong, because I think you can just go back to the Puerto Rico Supreme Court with a declaration that that statute is unconstitutional and that Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think the rule of the majority rule applies to declarations of unconstitutionality?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is what the statute -- the constitution provision says that, that particular Court may not hold a statute unconstitutional without that "super-majority".
If this Court holds it unconstitutional, that Court can certainly enter judgment in favor of the appellant.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It does not say that it may not satisfy judgments for reasons of unconstitutionality?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't the Court have reversed the judgment in this and not violated the statute?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: And not violated Public Law 22?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: The Court's specific holding --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Four-to-three, four-to-three say that this judgment must be reversed?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Without any reference to the Puerto Rico statute?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I think there are two responses to that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They did not think so.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: First is they did not think so.
First is they clearly did not think so, and they are the ones who interpret what that constitution provision means.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And they are bound to that?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Yes, under this Court's decision in Fornaro, you are bound by the Puerto Rico Supreme Court's interpretation of its own constitutional provision unless that interpretation is inescapably wrong, and it certainly not inescapably wrong.
Secondly, I think it would be disingenuous.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the thing that really bothers me is Puerto Rico required to give you an appeal [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: By what?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: By Puerto Rico criminal statutes by Rule 3 of the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Not by our constitution?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct, no.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What case of controversy in this Court, in light of the Puerto Rico's position in this Court, what is the case of controversy over the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: The controversy is --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Over the Fourth Amendment, only over that question?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I would say if the state now concedes that issue, there is no more controversy --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Incidentally, Puerto Rico is not a state, is it?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: It's correct, thank you.
There is no more controversy over that then it would be after a court entered judgment, if anyone anywhere along the line gave up on that issue.
They have given up on that issue, fine, let us remand it, if they have, let us remand it to Puerto Rican Supreme Court for --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But they still could not enter the declaration?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Unless one of dissenters below now joined the four majority.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: We just remand it then for reconsideration in light of this concession; that would not change the result if everybody stays for years and they obey the rule because the rule still forbid them from declaring the statute unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Let me put it differently.
If we had --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let us begin that at 1 o'clock.
You may continue counsel.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
I want to make a few comments about what was raised in the – giving before the lunch hour. First this Court is not bound by the concessions of a government.
In Sibron versus New York for example, the Kings County prosecutor conceded that, that statute had been violated.

And this Court pointed out that concessions by the parties do not relieve it from what it called the obligation to perform a judicial function, where federal constitutional rights in state courts are decided and where this Court is already had the benefit of full briefing and argument on that Fourth Amendment claim, it seems to me that the concession of the government would not bind this Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that might be true when the lower court happen to disagree, but it did not?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, the judgment of the lower court is still a contrary.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The only reason you lost in the lower court was because of the local rule about upsetting a statute?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, if Puerto Rico had a rule which say that –-

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't that right, they have agreed with you on the Fourth Amendment?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: They did, that is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Four–to–two?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Four–to–two, that is right.

If Puerto Rico had a rule that there was no appeal allowed at all from a decision by a lower court, we would be -- and the lower court had upheld the statute, this Court would have full authority to decide that statute.

The fact that there was no appellate review at least putting aside the question of whether it is required, at least would not be considered in independent state ground to uphold the judgment of the lower court.
And what is happened is that the Puerto Rico Supreme Court has taken Article V, Section 4 and said that renders it powerless in a sense to decide this appeal.
And if that is true, it is no different then if we directly here from the judgment of the Superior Court, which is a judgment in question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it has decided the appeal, it is affirmed that your client is, one of my colleagues pointed out before, has a judgment of conviction outstanding against him, so that however, whatever the voting rules are down there in San Juan, you lost?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is right we lost, but we can hardly be in a worst position than if we had no right to appeal at all.

I agree we lost, but that court in affirming the judgment, we are saying no more than it was not going to rule on that appeal, even though it believed -- the majority believed that the statute was unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did it not rule on the appeal?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: It affirmed the judgment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Okay, but on the grounds it was paroles to do otherwise and that is no different, than if there were no appeal available at all.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, is that quite an accurate description of that.
If we say that the local rule of what you have called I think the "super-majority" is a valid rule, does that not end the case?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: No, it does not because if that is a valid rule, the effect of upholding that rule is to leave a statute which the government of Puerto Rico itself concedes is not constitutional in full place and in full effect.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You say that is not in adequate state ground too, beside the case is on, this special majority rule?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I think the adequate state ground thing is somewhat different.
The adequate state ground in the classic sense is when there is a constitutional provision gives more rights than the federal constitution allows.
This Court has said in the past that a local procedural rule which this is of the state cannot be used to foreclose federal constitutional right, you did that in Chambers --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if it had happened that your Fourth Amendment issue had not been properly raised in the lower court and the Puerto Rican Supreme Court said, we just will not rule on that, because you did not raise it as our rules require and so we affirm the judgment.

Now if you came here, we would say that we would deny or dismiss because of an adequate state ground, but it would not foreclose you from federal -- would not necessarily foreclose you from federal habeas?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, the Court has in the past with respect to procedural rules other than even handed -- procedure rules which interfere with the vindication of federal constitutional rights have not stuck down in the past by the Court, which have been –-

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: [Inaudible] procedural rule, is it not a procedural rule.
There is a little bit of substance here.

turn.text: That is correct; there was nothing about this being untimely.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, we do not know they denied it as out of time or --

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: We do not know that.

We do know that there is an appellate procedure, which suggests that the court should not file one, which is out of time and it may very well be that the court directed to file this one, fully considered it, denied it on the merits.
But I think the inference is that it was heard on the merits, it was heard en banc.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why is that the inference?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Because of the Section of 45 (b), which states that a petition for rehearing ought not to be filed if it is late by the clerk and then there is a certain inconsistency between that and 45 (d).

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that a rule [Voice Overlap]

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Yes, such we printed in the governments motion to dismiss or affirm at page 7.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I mean that the rule itself?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Yes the rule.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Rule 45?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Yes, they are reprinted.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: At page what?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Page 7 of the government's motion to dismiss or affirm.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, thank you.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose they did deny it on the merits and do you want us to say that they were wrong in denying it?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And in namely, you want us to agree with you in your petition for rehearing and declare that, that provision of the Puerto Rican Constitution is invalid under the federal constitution?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct, I am not so sure --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that the least but inconsistent with the Ohio case?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Oh!
I think that there is a certain inconsistency there, but the Ohio case first off is 48 years of due process.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you would really say that we should really upset the Ohio case?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: I do not think it is necessary, because the Ohio had two things this case does not.
First of all, it was a civil case and second, there was already intermediate full appellate review in the Ohio court, so that case can certainly be distinguished.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, several years ago, this Court upheld a 60% majority requirement for a bond approval in West Virginia, didn't it?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, I think that bond approval matters and those were to civil matters have historically been treated very, very differently from the enforcement of federal constitutions rights.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Remcho, I must say, wasn't this rule 45 or rather [Inaudible] any motion for reconsideration must, if the aforementioned term of ten working days and then in the last sentence, the clerk shall deny outright any petition for extension to file a motion for reconsideration.

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: Well, I think there is a certain inconsistency between that and between 45(d), which appears on page 7, which says any motion for reconsideration filed out of the aforementioned terms shall be considered by the court only to the extent that it does not effect the mandate and here of course the mandate had already been stayed.
Frankly it appears --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It would have affected the mandate somewhat.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the court did deny it?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct, it denied it but --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You can say, they were so agreed by the court and say by the clerk?

turn.speaker: joseph_remcho
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Remcho
turn.text: That is correct, but the court did allow its clerk to file that petition for reconsideration and it acted on it en banc, which suggests that it gave very stressful consideration.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
